associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText: THE LOADING CAPACITY IS CALCULATED AS THE MASS OF SUSPENDED SOLIDS WHICH WOULD RESULT IN A LAKE WATER CONCENTRATION OF 20 MG/L OF TOTAL SUSPENDED SOLIDS(TSS).  WITH A LAKE VOLUME OF 30.8 MILLION CUBIC METERS THIS WOULD BE 680 TONS IN SUSPENSION AT ANY ONE TIME.  THE PRESENT LOAD IS CALCULATED AT 1,620 TONS RESULTING IN AND IN-LAKE TSS CONCENTRATIONS OF 48 MG/L.  THE TMDL CALLS FOR A REDUCTION OF 28 MG/L OR 940 TONS.  THIS TARGETED SUSPENDED SOLIDS CONCENTRATION SHOULD MEET APPLICABLE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS.

LOADING CAPACITY FOR NUTRIENTS IS CALCULATED AS POUNDS OF PHOSPHORUS PER YEAR TO MEET A TROPHIC STATE INDEX (TSI) OF <62.  THE TSI RELATES PHOSPHORUS TO CHLOROPHYLL AND SECCHI DEPTH WHICH ARE USED TO DESCRIBE WATER QUALITY THAT WILL MEET IOWA'S NARRTIVE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS.  IN THIS TMDL THE LIMIT IS SET AT THE PRESENT VALUE , 19,520 POUNDS PER YEAR, BECAUSE THE TSIS FOR CHLOROPHYLL AND SECCHI DEPTH ARE PRESENTLY BEING MET. THE NUMERIC TARGET FOR SILTATION IS A SEDIMENT LOAD WHICH WILL NOT DECREASE THE VOLUME OF THE LAKE BY MORE THAN ONE THIRD OVER THE DESIGN LIFE OF 100 YEARS.  THIS IS SET AT 34,500 TONS PER YEAR.  MEETING THE TARGETS GIVEN IN THIS TMDL SHOULD RESULT IN THE ATTAINMENT OF WATER QUALITY STANDARDS FOR NUTRIENTS AND SILTATION.

MEETING THE TARGETS GIVEN IN THIS TMDL SHOULD RESULT IN THE ATTAINMENT OF WATER QUALITY STANDARDS FOR NUTRIENTS AND SILTATION.

LOADING CAPACITY FOR NUTRIENTS IS CALCULATED AS POUNDS OF PHOSPHORUS PER YEAR TO ATTAIN A CARLSON'S TROPHIC STATE INDEX (TSI) OF <65 FOR PHOSPHORUS, CHLOROPHYLL AND SECCHI DEPTH.  THE TSI RELATES PHOSPHORUS TO CHLOROPHYLL AND SECCHI DEPTH WHICH ARE USED TO DESCRIBE WATER QUALITY THAT WILL MEET IOWA'S NARRTIVE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS.  IN THIS TMDL THE ANNUAL PHOSPHORUS LOAD IS SET AT 2,540 POUNDS. THE NUMERIC TARGET FOR SILTATION IS A SEDIMENT LOAD SET AT 5,400 TONS PER YEAR.  MEETING THE TARGETS GIVEN IN THIS TMDL SHOULD RESULT IN THE ATTAINMENT OF WATER QUALITY STANDARDS FOR NUTRIENTS AND SILTATION.

THE TSI RELATES PHOSPHORUS TO CHLOROPHYLL AND SECCHI DEPTH WHICH ARE USED TO DESCRIBE WATER QUALITY THAT WILL MEET IOWA'S NARRTIVE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS. THE LINKAGE FOR ALGAE AND TURBIDITY IS DEFINED THROUGH CARLSON�S TSI.  THIS LINKAGE IS INDICATED BY A RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN TP, CHLOROPHYLL, AND WATER TRANSPARENCY SEEN IN A GROUP OF REFERENCE LAKES.  NUTRIENT RATIOS SUGGEST SOME PHOSPHORUS LIMITATION.  ADDITIONALLY, PHOSPHORUS IS TARGETED BECAUSE OF BLUE-GREEN ALGAE�S ABILITY TO FIX ATMOSPHERIC NITROGEN AND THE OVERABUNDANCE OF PHOSPHORUS INPUTS.  THE VOLLENWEIDER 1982 SHALLOW LAKE MODEL WAS SELECTED FOR THE TOTAL PHOSPHORUS TMDL LOADS DETERMINED IN THIS REPORT.  REDUCTIONS IN TOTAL PHOSPHORUS RE EXPECTED TO RESULT IN SIMILAR REDUCTIONS IN SUSPENDED SOLIDS.  EXCLUDING BACKGROUND SOURCES, THE AVERAGE ANNUAL PHOSPHORUS LOAD TO LITTLE WALL LAKE ORIGINATES ENTIRELY FROM NONPOINT SOURCES AND INTERNAL RECYCLING.  TO MEET THE TMDL ENDPOINT, THE ANNUAL NONPOINT SOURCE CONTRIBUTIONS TO LITTLE WALL LAKE MUST BE REDUCED TO LEVELS CORRESPONDING TO AN IN-LAKE TOTAL PHOSPHORUS CONCENTRATION OF LESS THAN 68 UG/L.  FOR EXAMPLE, IF THERE IS A PUMPED FLOW (ACRE-FEET PER YEAR) OF 100 AND ALLOWABLE LOAD (POUNDS PER YEAR) OF 250 AND LOAD ALLOCATION (ALLOWABLE LOAD MINUS 10% MARGIN OF SAFETY � POUNDS PER YEAR) OF 230.

TO ACHIEVE WQS BASED ON NARRATIVE STANDARDS THAT "SUCH WATERS SHALL BE FREE FROM... OBJECTIONABLE COLOR, ODOR, AND OTHER AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS." NOXIOUS AQUATIC PLANTS ARE ASSOCIATED WITH EXCESSIVE NUTRIENT (PHOSPHOROUS)LOADING.  A LINK WAS ESTABLISHED BETWEEN TROPHIC STATE INDEX (TSI) AND THE CONCENTRATION FOR TOTAL PHOSPHORUS TO THE QUANTITY OF ALGAE AND TURBIDITY IN THE SYSTEM. A TSI WAS ESTABLISHED FOR TOTAL PHOSPHORUS <70 AND A TSI FOR CHLOROPHYLL AND SECCHI DEPTH <65.

THE LINKAGE FOR TURBIDITY IS DEFINED THROUGH CARLSON�S TSI VALUES.  SINCE THE STATE DOES NOT HAVE NUMERIC WATER QUALITY CRITERIA FOR TURBIDITY THE TDML USES THE SURROGATE MEASURE OF TSI WHICH LINKS THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN TP AND WATER TRANSPARENCY WITH TURBIDITY CONDITIONS.  SEDIMENT AND NUTRIENTS FROM THE WATERSHED OR RESUSPENDED FROM WITHIN THE LAKE ARE CAUSING INCREASED TURBIDITY AND MAY CAUSE INCREASED ALGAL BLOOMS.  THEREFORE, THE TMDL IS TARGETING BOTH SEDIMENT LOADS AD PHOSPHORUS LOADS.  PHOSPHORUS IS BEING TARGETED BECAUSE THERE MAY BE IMPACTS DUE TO INCREASED LIGHT PENETRATION WHICH COULD LEAD TO INCREASED ALGAL BLOOMS.  GROWING SEASON MEAN (GSW) IN-LAKE TOTAL PHOSPHORUS CONCENTRATIONS ARE USED TO CALCULATE AN ANNUAL AVERAGE TOTAL PHOSPHORUS LOADING.  TO ACHIEVE A LAKE PHOSPHORUS TSI OF 70, THE PHOSPHORUS LOADING CAPACITY OF WILLIAMSON POND WAS BASED ON THE VOLLENWEIDER 1982 SHALLOW LAKE AND RESERVOIR MODEL.  REDUCTIONS IN TOTAL PHOSPHORUS AND SUSPENDED SEDIMENTS ARE EXPECTED TO RESULT IN SIMILAR REDUCTIONS IN NON-ALGAL TURBIDITY.  THE LOAD ALLOCATIONS AND MARGIN OF SAFETY DO NOT EXCEED THE LOAD CAPACITY.  THE LOAD ALLOCATION FOR TURBIDITY 349 TONS/YEAR OF SEDIMENT IN THE LAKE ALLOCATED TO NONPOINT SOURCES, AND LAKE RESUSPENSION.  THE LOAD ALLOCATION FOR PHOSPHORUS IS SET AT 724 LBS/YEAR.

"WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
AS OF JULY 2003, E. COLI IS NOW THE INDICATOR BACTERIUM (NOT FECAL COLIFORM) AND APPLIES TO WATERS DESIGNATED AS PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION CLASS A1, SECONDARY CONTACT CLASS 2, OR CHILDREN'S RECREATIONAL CLASS A3 USES.  THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES' (IDNR) 2006 SECTION 305(B) ASSESSMENT REPORT (IDNR, 2007B) IDENTIFIED NINE SEGMENTS WITHIN THE CEDAR RIVER WATERSHED AS EITHER ""NOT SUPPORTING"" OR ""PARTIALLY SUPPORTING"" BECAUSE OF LEVELS OF INDICATOR BACTERIA THAT EXCEED THAT STATE CRITERIA.  THE APPLICABLE WQS FOR INDICATOR BACTERIA E. COLI ARE A SEASONAL GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126 CFU/100 ML AND A SINGLE MAXIMUM VALUE OF 235 CFU/100 ML (IOWA ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (IAC) CHAPTER 61.3(3)(1)).  THESE WQS ARE APPLIED TO SURFACE WATER DURING THE RECREATION SEASON, WHICH IS FROM MARCH 15 TO NOVEMBER 15.  ALL SEGMENTS ARE DESIGNATED FOR WARM WATER AQUATIC LIFE TYPE 1(CLASS B_(WW-1)), AND FISH CONSUMPTION HUMAN HEALTH (HH).  SEGMENT 02-CED-0030_2 IS ALSO DESIGNATED FOR DRINKING WATER SUPPLY (CLASS C), AND SEGMENT 02-CED-0020_2, IS ALSO DESIGNATED AS A HIGH QUALITY WATER (CLASS HQR).

TO ACHIEVE WQS, THIS TMDL HAS CALCULATED A LOAD CAPACITY AS POUNDS OF PHOSPHORUS TO MEET A TROPHIC STATE INDEX (TSI) OF <66.  THIS TSI RELATES PHOSPHORUS TO CHLOROPHYLL AND SECCHI DEPTH WHICH ARE USED TO DESCRIBE WQ. THE LOAD CAPACITY IS 12,440 LBS/YR PHOSPHORUS.
TO ACHIEVE WQS, THE SEDIMENT LOAD WILL NOT DECREASE THE VOLUME OF THE LAKE BY MORE THAN ONE THIRD OVER THE DESIGN LIFE OF 100 YEARS. THE LOAD CAPACITY FOR SEDIMENT IS 11,600 TONS/YEAR.

TO ACHIEVE WQS THE NUMERIC TARGET FOR SILTATION IS A SEDIMENT LOAD WHICH WILL NOT DECREASE THE VOLUME OF THE LAKE BY MORE THAN ONE THIRD OVER THE DESIGN LIFE OF 80 YEARS.  THE LOAD CAPACITY IS 1,570 TONS/YR SEDIMENT.

TO ACHIEVE WQS, THE TMDL LINKS PHOSPHORUS LOADING TO CARLSON'S TROPHIC STATE INDEX (TSI) OF <70 WHICH WILL RESULT IN THE ACHIEVEMENT OF TSI <65 FOR CHLOROPHYLL AND SECCHI DEPTH. THIS WILL ADDRESS THE NOXIOUS AQUATIC PLANT AND ORGANIC ENRICHMENT IMPAIRMENTS.
Please refer to the TMDL for specific loading information for Total Phosphorus to address the Algae and Turbidity pollutants.

TO ACHIEVE WQS, THE TMDL LINKS PHOSPHORUS LOADING TO CARLSON'S TROPHIC STATE INDEX (TSI) OF <70 WHICH WILL RESULT IN THE ACHIEVEMENT OF TSI <65 FOR CHLOROPHYLL AND SECCHI DEPTH. THIS WILL ADDRESS THE NOXIOUS AQUATIC PLANT AND ORGANIC ENRICHMENT IMPAIRMENTS.

TO ACHIEVE WQS THE LOAD CAPACITY IS 370 TONS/YR OF SEDIMENT.  THE EXISTING LOAD IS 680 TONS/YR. THIS REQUIRES A 310 TON/YR REDUCTION, WHICH WILL INCREASE TRANSPARENCY TO THE TARGET SECCHI DEPTH OF 0.7 METERS.
Refer to the TMDL for specific loading information.

TO ACHIEVE THE WQS, THE TMDL HAS LINKED NOXIOUS AQUATIC PLANTS WITH EXCESSIVE NUTRIENT LOADINGS. REDUCING THE TOTAL PHOSPHORUS LOAD TO 670 LBS/YR WILL RESULT IN ATTAINMENT OF WQS. CARLSON'S TROPHIC STATE INDEX (TSI) HAS BEEN USED TO LINK PHOSPHORUS WITH CHLOROPHYLL AND SECCHI DEPTH.  THE TSI FOR PHOSPHORUS IS < 70, THIS WILL RESULT IN CHLOROPHYLL AND SECCHI DEPTH TSIS OF BOTH <65.

THIS TARGET SHOULD RESULT IN THE TSI CHLOROPHYLL AND TSI SECCHI DEPTH BOTH <65.  THE PHOSPHOROUS LOADING CAPACITY IS 9,500 LBS/YR.

THIS TARGET SHOULD RESULT IN THE TSI FOR CHLOROPHYLL AND SECCHI DEPTH, BOTH <65.  THE PHOSPHORUS LOADING CAPACITY IS 9,500 LBS/YR.

THE BIG SIOUX RIVER'S LC IS EXPRESSED THROUGH THE USED OF LOAD DURATION CURVES (LDC) FOR EACH OF THE IMPAIRED SEGMENTS.  NUMERIC EXPRESSIONS OF THE LDC ARE GIVEN IN TABULAR FORM FOR EACH POINT SOURCE AND BY HUC12 AND FLOW RANGE FOR LCS.  THE NUMERIC TARGET USED TO CALCULATE EACH LDC IS THE SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM E. COLI CONCENTRATION (IA) OR FECAL COLIFORM CONCENTRATION (SD) OF 235 AND 400 COLONY FORMING UNITS (CFU) PER 100 ML RESPECTIVELY.  THE TMDL IDENTIFIES REQUIRED REDUCTIONS OF FROM 0 - 99.8% DEPENDING ON SEGMENT AND PERCENTILE OF FLOW EXCEEDANCE TO MEET WQS.

THE EPA CONCURS THAT MEETING THE TMDL TARGETS WILL RESULT IN THE ATTAINMENT OF WQS IN THE BIG SIOUX RIVER.

THE DESIGNATED BENEFICIAL USES FOR ALL SEGMENTS OF THE BIG SIOUX RIVER COVERED BY THIS TMDL ARE: IN IOWA, CLASS A, PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION, AND CLASS B, AQUATIC LIFE; IN SOUTH DAKOTA, IMMERSION AND LIMITED CONTACT RECREATION, WARM WATER SEMI-PERMANENT FISH LIFE, FISH AND WILDLIFE PROPAGATION, RECREATION AND STOCK WATERING, AND IRRIGATION WATERING.  THE USE THAT IS IMPAIRED IS: FOR IOWA, CLASS A PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION; FOR SOUTH DAKOTA, IMMERSION RECREATION.

74:51:01:50.  CRITERIA FOR IMMERSION RECREATION WATERS. THE CRITERIA OF PARAMETERS FOR IMMERSION RECREATION WATERS AND THEIR ALLOWABLE VARIATIONS THAT ARE NOT INCLUDED UNDER § 74:51:01:55 AND APPENDIX B, UNLESS SET UNDER § 74:51:01:24, ARE AS FOUND IN THE FOLLOWING TABLE:

PARAMETER CRITERIA UNIT OF MEASURE SPECIAL CONDITIONS 
FECAL COLIFORM
(MAY 1  SEPTEMBER 30) < 200 /100 ML GEOMETRIC MEAN BASED ON A MINIMUM OF 5 SAMPLES OBTAINED DURING SEPARATE 24-HOUR PERIODS FOR ANY 30-DAY PERIOD, AND THEY MAY NOT EXCEED THIS VALUE IN MORE THAN 20 PERCENT OF THE SAMPLES EXAMINED IN THIS SAME 30-DAY PERIOD 
 < 400  IN ANY ONE SAMPLE 


THE IMPAIRMENT IS APPLICABLE DURING THE IOWA RECREATION SEASON WHICH BEGINS EARLIER, MARCH 15, AND ENDS LATER, NOVEMBER 15, THAN THE SOUTH DAKOTA RECREATION SEASON.  THE IOWA SEASON IS APPLICABLE BECAUSE AS A BOUNDARY WATER THE TMDL MUST BE PROTECTIVE OF THE MOST STRINGENT WQS.  

THE TMDL TARGETS NUMERIC CRITERIA (SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMA) FOR BOTH STATES.  FOR IOWA THIS IS E. COLI AND FOR SOUTH DAKOTA, FECAL COLIFORM BACTERIA.

THE BIG SIOUX RIVER'S LC IS EXPRESSED THROUGH THE USED OF LOAD DURATION CURVES (LDC) FOR EACH OF THE IMPAIRED SEGMENTS.  NUMERIC EXPRESSIONS OF THE LDC ARE GIVEN IN TABULAR FORM FOR EACH POINT SOURCE AND BY HUC12 AND FLOW RANGE FOR LCS.  THE NUMERIC TARGET USED TO CALCULATE EACH LDC IS THE SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM E. COLI CONCENTRATION (IA) OR FECAL COLIFORM CONCENTRATION (SD) OF 235 AND 400 COLONY FORMING UNITS (CFU) PER 100 ML RESPECTIVELY.  THE TMDL IDENTIFIES REQUIRED REDUCTIONS OF FROM 0 - 99.8% DEPENDING ON SEGMENT AND PERCENTILE OF FLOW EXCEEDANCE TO MEET WQS.

THE EPA CONCURS THAT MEETING THE TMDL TARGETS WILL RESULT IN THE ATTAINMENT OF WQS IN THE BIG SIOUX RIVER.

THE DESIGNATED BENEFICIAL USES FOR ALL SEGMENTS OF THE BIG SIOUX RIVER COVERED BY THIS TMDL ARE: IN IOWA, CLASS A, PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION, AND CLASS B, AQUATIC LIFE; IN SOUTH DAKOTA, IMMERSION AND LIMITED CONTACT RECREATION, WARM WATER SEMI-PERMANENT FISH LIFE, FISH AND WILDLIFE PROPAGATION, RECREATION AND STOCK WATERING, AND IRRIGATION WATERING.  THE USE THAT IS IMPAIRED IS: FOR IOWA, CLASS A PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION; FOR SOUTH DAKOTA, IMMERSION RECREATION.

"WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
LAKE KEOMAH IS A SIGNIFICANT PUBLICLY OWNED LAKE, AND IS PROTECTED FOR THE FOLLOWING DESIGNATED USES: PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATIONAL USE CLASS A1, LAKES AND WETLANDS AQUATIC LIFE CLASS B(LW), HUMAN HEALTH FISH CONSUMPTION CLASS HH AND DRINKING WATER SUPPLY CLASS C.
 
ALGAE

ALTHOUGH THE STATE OF IOWA DOES NOT HAVE NUMERIC CRITERIA FOR ALGAE OR CHLOROPHYLL A, NARRATIVE WATER QUALITY CRITERIA DO APPLY. CHAPTER 61.3(2) OF THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS CONTAINS THE GENERAL WATER QUALITY CRITERIA, WHICH ARE APPLICABLE TO ALL SURFACE WATERS. 
 
61.3(2)C.  ""SUCH WATERS SHALL BE FREE FROM MATERIALS ATTRIBUTABLE TO WASTEWATER DISCHARGES OR AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES PRODUCING OBJECTIONABLE COLOR, ODOR OR OTHER AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS.""
 

THE NARRATIVE CRITERIA IN THE WQS REQUIRE THAT LAKE KEOMAH BE FREE FROM ¿AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS.¿ THERE ARE NO NUMERIC CRITERIA ASSOCIATED WITH WATER CLARITY; THEREFORE, ATTAINMENT OF THE WQS IS BASED ON MAINTAINING RELATIVELY GOOD WATER CLARITY COMPARED TO OTHER IOWA LAKES. THE PRIMARY METRIC FOR WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT SET FORTH IN THIS TMDL IS OBTAINING/ MAINTAINING A CHLOROPHYLL A CARLSON'S TROPHIC STATE INDEX OF NO GREATER THAN 63, WHICH CORRESPONDS TO A CHLOROPHYLL A CONCENTRATION OF 27 MICROGRAMS PER LITER. THE IDNR CONSIDERS AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS PRESENT IN A WATER BODY WHEN CARLSON¿S TSI FOR THE MEDIAN GROWING SEASON CHLOROPHYLL A OR SECCHI DEPTH EXCEEDS 65. IN ORDER TO DELIST A LAKE IMPAIRED BY ALGAE FROM THE 303(D) LIST, THE MEDIAN GROWING SEASON CHLOROPHYLL A TSI MUST NOT EXCEED 63 IN TWO CONSECUTIVE LISTING CYCLES, PER THE IDNR'S DELISTING METHODOLOGY. TO AVOID EXCEEDING A TSI VALUE OF 63, THE MEDIAN GROWING SEASON CHLOROPHYLL A CONCENTRATION MUST NOT EXCEED 27 UG/L.
 
PH

WITH RESPECT TO PH, THE SAME NUMERIC CRITERIA APPLY TO PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATIONAL USE CLASS A1, LAKES AND WETLANDS AQUATIC LIFE CLASS B(LW) AND DRINKING WATER SUPPLY CLASS C. 
 
PER SECTIONS 61.3(3)A(2), B(2) AND C(3) OF THE WQS, ""THE PH SHALL NOT BE LESS THAN 6.5 NOR GREATER THAN 9.0.""

THE IDNR CONSIDERS AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS PRESENT IN A WATER BODY WHEN CARLSON¿S TSI FOR THE MEDIAN GROWING SEASON CHLOROPHYLL A OR SECCHI DEPTH EXCEEDS 65. IN ORDER TO DELIST A LAKE IMPAIRED BY ALGAE FROM THE 303(D) LIST, THE MEDIAN GROWING SEASON CHLOROPHYLL A TSI MUST NOT EXCEED 63 IN TWO CONSECUTIVE LISTING CYCLES, PER THE IDNR'S DELISTING METHODOLOGY. TO AVOID EXCEEDING A TSI VALUE OF 63, THE MEDIAN GROWING SEASON CHLOROPHYLL A CONCENTRATION MUST NOT EXCEED 27 UG/L.
 
PH

WITH RESPECT TO PH, THE SAME NUMERIC CRITERIA APPLY TO PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATIONAL USE CLASS A1, LAKES AND WETLANDS AQUATIC LIFE CLASS B(LW) AND DRINKING WATER SUPPLY CLASS C. 
 
PER SECTIONS 61.3(3)A(2), B(2) AND C(3) OF THE WQS, ""THE PH SHALL NOT BE LESS THAN 6.5 NOR GREATER THAN 9.0.""

NUMERIC TARGET(S):
LAKE KEOMAH IS A SIGNIFICANT PUBLICLY OWNED LAKE, AND IS PROTECTED FOR THE FOLLOWING DESIGNATED USES: PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATIONAL USE CLASS A1, LAKES AND WETLANDS AQUATIC LIFE CLASS B(LW), HUMAN HEALTH FISH CONSUMPTION CLASS HH AND DRINKING WATER SUPPLY CLASS C.
 
ALGAE

ALTHOUGH THE STATE OF IOWA DOES NOT HAVE NUMERIC CRITERIA FOR ALGAE OR CHLOROPHYLL A, NARRATIVE WATER QUALITY CRITERIA DO APPLY. CHAPTER 61.3(2) OF THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS CONTAINS THE GENERAL WATER QUALITY CRITERIA, WHICH ARE APPLICABLE TO ALL SURFACE WATERS. 
 
61.3(2)C.  ""SUCH WATERS SHALL BE FREE FROM MATERIALS ATTRIBUTABLE TO WASTEWATER DISCHARGES OR AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES PRODUCING OBJECTIONABLE COLOR, ODOR OR OTHER AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS.""

MCLOUD'S HEAT LOADING CAPACITY RANGES FROM 6.0 X 105 TO 3.3 X 107 KILOGOULES PER DAY DEPENDING ON FLOW CONDITIONS.  WQS THAT APPLY TO MCLOUD RUN INCLUDE A MAXIMUM WATER TEMPERATURE INCREASE OF 1 DEGREE CELSIUS PER HOUR. THIS TARGET IS BASED ON ACUTE CHANGES IN WATER TEMPERATURE RESULTING FROM DIRECT, ANTHROPOGENIC ADDITIONS OF HEAT TO THE STREAM (POINT SOURCES).  THERE ARE TWO POINT SOURCES IN THE WATERSHED (MS4S) ONE IN CEDAR RAPIDS AND ONE IN HIAWATHA.  THE WLA ALLOCATION IS DIVIDED BETWEEN THE TWO POINT SOURCES BASED ONTHEIR RESPECTIVE AREA'S CONTRIBUTION TO MCLOUD RUN.  87% TO CEDAR RAPIDS' MS4 AND 13% TO HIAWATHA'S MS4. REFER TO THE TMDL FOR MORE SPECIFIC INFORMATION.  THIS TMDL'S TARGET AND ALLOCATIONS WILL RESULT IN MEETING WQS.
3.0 MICROGRAMS/L

THE POLLUTANTS ARE DEFINED AS ALGAE AND TURBIDITY LINKED TO EXCESSIVE NUTRIENT LAODING.  PHOSPHORUS IS TARGETED AT THE POLLUTANT TO REDUCE IMPAIRMENTS.  THIS TMDL WAS SCHEDULED AS HIGH PRIORITY FOR DEVELOPMENT.  CARLSON'S TROPHIC STATE INDEX WAS USED TO LINK THE CONCENTRATION OF TOTAL PHOSPHORUS TO THE QUATITY OF ALGAE AND TURDBIDITY INT HE SYSTEM.  A TSI FOR TOTAL PHOSPHORUS <70 WAS SET AS A TARGET TO ACHIEVE TSI FOR CHOLORPHYLL (ALGAE) AND SECCHI DEPTH (TURBIDITY) OF <65. TSIS OF <65 WOULD MEET THE NARRATIVE STANDARD FOR ALGAE AND TURBIDITY.  THE LOAD CAPACITY FOR PHOSPHORUS IS SET AT 1,462 POUNDS PER YEAR TO RESULT IN ATTAINMENT OF WQS. THIS TMDL IS SHARED BETWEEN NE AND IA AND THE PERMIT WLA LIMITS ARE DIFFERENT FOR EACH STATE, CHECK WITH THE RESPECTIVE STATE'S TMDL DOCUMENT FOR SPECIFIC PERMIT LOADING.

"WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
THE STREAM'S DESIGNATED USES ARE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION (CLASS A1) AND AQUATIC LIFE (CLASS B WW-2). SILVER CREEK IS IMPAIRED FOR AQUATIC LIFE (CLASS B WW-2). THE TMDL WAS WRITTEN FOR SEDIMENT AND AMMONIA. EXCESS SEDIMENT REDUCES THE AVAILABILITY OF SPAWNING HABITAT FOR FISH AND BURIES DESIRABLE HABITAT FOR BENTHIC MACROINVERTEBRATES, THUS REDUCING THE BENTHIC MACROINVERTEBRATES INDEX OF BIOTIC INTEGRITY AND THE FISH INDEX OF BIOTIC INTEGRITY SCORES. INCREASED LEVELS OF EPISODIC AMMONIA LEAD TO DEPLETED DISSOLVED OXYGEN CONDITIONS AND TOXICITY ISSUES FOR FISH AND BENTHIC MACROINVERTEBRATES WITHIN THE IMPAIRED SEGMENT OF SILVER CREEK. 
 
THE TMDL STATES THAT THE STATE OF IOWA WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ARE PUBLISHED IN THE IOWA ADMINISTRATIVE CODE, ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION RULE 567, CHAPTER 61. THE IDNR DOES NOT HAVE A NUMERIC CRITERIA FOR SEDIMENT, NARRATIVE WQS DO APPLY. CHAPTER 61.3(2)(C)(E) OF THE WQS CONTAINS THE GENERAL WQS CRITERIA THAT IS APPLICABLE TO ALL SURFACE WATERS. THE NARRATIVE CRITERIA READS THAT:

""WATERS SHALL BE FROM MATERIALS ATTRIBUTABLE TO WASTEWATER DISCHARGES OR AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES PRODUCING OBJECTIONABLE COLOR, ODOR, OR OTHER AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS""
""WATERS SHALL BE FREE FROM SUBSTANCES, ATTRIBUTABLE TO WASTEWATER DISCHARGES OR AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, IN QUANTITIES WHICH WOULD PRODUCE UNDESIRABLE OR NUISANCE AQUATIC LIFE."" 
 
THE TARGET FOR SEDIMENT LOADING TO SILVER CREEK IS 3,285 TONS PER YEAR. EXISTING DAILY LOADS ARE 14,930 TONS/YEAR. A 78 PERCENT REDUCTION IN CURRENT ANNUAL SEDIMENT DELIVERY TO THE STREAM IS NEEDED TO ACHIEVE THE TMDL TARGET. THE ULTIMATE ENDPOINT OF THIS TMDL IS TO ACHIEVE AND MAINTAIN THE BENTHIC MACROINVERTEBRATES INDEX OF BIOTIC INTEGRITY AND THE FISH INDEX OF BIOTIC INTEGRITY SCORES OF AT LEAST 61 AND 52, CONSECUTIVELY. REDUCTIONS IN SEDIMENT WILL ALSO NEED TO MEET THE NARRATIVE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS FOR ""AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS."" ONCE THE ENDPOINTS ARE MAINTAINED AND ACHIEVED, ATTAINMENT OF WQS WILL BE MET.
 
THE IDNR HAS NUMERIC CRITERIA FOR AMMONIA IN CHAPTER 61.3(3), BUT STANDARDS VARY DEPENDING ON PH AND TEMPERATURE OF THE WATER; THEREFORE, THERE IS NO SINGLE NUMERIC CRITERION FOR AMMONIA. THE WQS CAN BE ACCESSED ON THE WEB AT HTTP://WWW.IOWADNR.COM/WATER/STANDARDS.FILES/CHAPTER61.PDF.
 THE LOADING CAPACITY FOR AMMONIA IS 12.33 POUNDS PER DAY. AMMONIA TOXICITY IS DEPENDENT ON TEMPERATURE AND PH. IDEALLY, THE CONTROLLING OF CHRONIC AMMONIA TOXICITY REQUIRES THE CONTROLLING OF EPISODIC RELEASES AS OPPOSED TO REDUCING AN EXISTING LOAD. THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS (WQS) FOR ACUTE AND CHRONIC AMMONIA TOXICITY FOR A RANGE OF PH CONDITIONS ARE SHOWN IN TABLE 3-5 OF THE TMDL DOCUMENT. THE WQS FOR CHRONIC AMMONIA TOXICITY, AND/OR MINIMUM DISSOLVED OXYGEN CRITERIA OF 5 MILLIGRAMS PER LITER (MG/L) MUST BE MET TO ACHIEVE ATTAINMENT OF WQS. 
 
AMMONIA DEPLETES DISSOLVED OXYGEN, THEREFORE, ANY SOURCE ASSESSMENT MUST CONSIDER THE EFFECTS OF EPISODIC AMMONIA RELEASES ON THE DISSOLVED OXYGEN LEVELS OF THE STREAM. FOR DISSOLVED OXYGEN, THE IDNR WQS CHAPTER 61.3(3)(B)(1) FOR CLASS B WW-2 USE STATES THAT DISSOLVED OXYGEN SHOULD NOT BE LESS THAN A MINIMUM VALUE OF 5.0 MG/L FOR A MINIMUM 16 HOURS OF EVERY 24-HOUR PERIOD. DISSOLVED OXYGEN SHOULD NOT BE LESS THAN A MINIMUM OF 4.0 MG/LFOR A MINIMUM AT ANY TIME DURING EVERY 24-HOUR PERIOD. THIS CRITERIA ONLY APPLIES TO THE UPPER LAYER STRATIFICATION IN LAKES. 
  
THE ULTIMATE ENDPOINT OF THIS TMDL IS TO ENSURE THE RESTORED CAPACITY OF SILVER CREEK IS PROTECTED AND TO ACHIEVE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS TO FULLY PROTECT ALL DESIGNATED USES.

NUMERIC TARGET(S):
THE STREAM'S DESIGNATED USES ARE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION (CLASS A1) AND AQUATIC LIFE (CLASS B WW-2). SILVER CREEK IS IMPAIRED FOR AQUATIC LIFE (CLASS B WW-2). THE TMDL WAS WRITTEN FOR SEDIMENT AND AMMONIA. EXCESS SEDIMENT R"

"WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
THE DESIGNATED USES LISTED FOR SILVER LAKE ARE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION (A), CLASS B (LW), AND FISH CONSUMPTION (HH).  THE SPECIFIC WATER QUALITY CRITERIA FOR THESE DESIGNATED USES LISTED BELOW ARE PUBLISHED IN THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION RULE 567, CHAPTER 61 WQS:
 
      SUBRULE 61.3(5) FOR CLASS A WATERS AND PH STATES, ""THE PH SHALL NOT BE LESS THAN 6.5 NOR GREATER THAN 9.0.  
THE MAXIMUM CHANGE PERMITTED AS A RESULT OF A WASTE DISCHARGE SHALL NOT EXCEED 0.5 PH UNITS.""  
 
     SUBRULE 61.3(5) 6(1) FOR CLASS B (LW) WATERS IS REFERENCED IN TABLE 2 OF THE IA WQS (CH.1, P.21).  THE MINIMUM VALUE AT ANY TIME DURING EVERY 24-HOUR PERIOD SHOULD BE 5.0 MG/L (MILLIGRAMS PER LITER).  THE VALUE OF 5.0 MG/L APPLIES ONLY TO THE UPPER LAYER OF STRATIFICATION IN LAKES.
 
      SUBRULE 61.3(3) STATES, ""THE WATERS SHALL CONTAIN NO SUBSTANCES IN CONCENTRATIONS WHICH WILL MAKE FISH OR SHELL-FISH INEDIBLE DUE TO UNDESIRABLE TASTES OR CAUSE A HAZARD TO HUMANS AFTER CONSUMPTION.""  SPECIFIC TOXIC CHEMICAL CRITERIA WERE ALSO AVAILABLE.
 
      TABLE 6 ON PAGE 23 OF THE TMDL LISTS THE ACUTE AMMONIA WATER QUALITY CRITERION FOR LISTED CLASSES.
 
THE 2006 305(B) REPORT STATES THAT THE CLASS A (PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION) USES WERE ASSESSED (MONITORED) AS 
""NOT SUPPORTED"" DUE TO 1) EXTREMELY POOR WATER TRANSPARENCY THAT VIOLATES IA'S WQS PROTECTING OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS AND 2) FREQUENT VIOLATIONS OF IA'S WATER QUALITY CRITERION FOR PH.  IN ADDITION, THE PRESENCE OF VERY LARGE POPULATIONS OF NUISANCE AQUATIC LIFE (BLUE-GREEN ALGAE) LIKELY REPRESENTS AN ADDITIONAL IMPAIRMENT TO THE CLASS A USES.  THE CLASS B (LW) AQUATIC USES WERE ASSESSED AS ""NOT SUPPORTED"" DUE TO VIOLATIONS OF STATE WATER QUALITY CRITERIA FOR DISSOLVED OXYGEN (DO) AND PH.  THE CLASS B (LW) USES WERE ALSO ASSESSED AS ""NOT SUPPORTED"" DUE TO EXCESSIVE NUTRIENT LOADING TO THE WATER COLUMN, NUISANCE BLOOMS OF ALGAE, AND RE-SUSPENSION OF SEDIMENT.  
 
AS PREVIOUSLY STATED, THE STATE OF IA HAS NO NUMERIC WATER QUALITY CRITERIA FOR ALGAE OR TURBIDITY.  THE ASSESSMENT PROTOCOL FROM THE IA 305(B) REPORT STATES THAT IF A LAKE IS DETERMINED IMPAIRED BY ALGAE OR TURBIDITY, THE TARGETS FOR THIS TMDL ARE A MEAN TSI VALUE OF LESS THAN 65 FOR BOTH CHLOROPHYLL-A AND SECCHI DEPTH.  THESE VALUES ARE NOTED TO BE EQUIVALENT TO A CHLOROPHYLL-A CONCENTRATION OF 33 ?G/L (MICROGRAMS PER LITER) AND A SECCHI DEPTH OF 0.7 METERS.  THIS IS HOW AND WHY THE INDICATED TARGETS ARE SET TO ASSIST IN THE ACHIEVEMENT OF INCREASED WATER QUALITY WITHIN SILVER LAKE.  CHAPTER 61 OF THE IA WQS WAS ALSO USED TO DETERMINE CRITERIA FOR THE WATER QUALITY AND IS AVAILABLE AT HTTP://WWW.IOWADNR.COM/WATER/STANDARDS/FILES/CHAPTER61.PDF FOR REFERENCE PURPOSES.
 
THIS REVISED TMDL USES DATA FROM THE INITIAL TMDL AND SUBSEQUENT SAMPLING RESULTS TO MORE ACCURATELY DEFINE PRESENT CONDITIONS WITHIN THE LAKE.  THE RE-EVALUATION HAS RESULTED IN A BETTER CHARACTERIZATION OF THE LAKE'S CONDITION AND RESPONSE OF THE ALGAL COMMUNITY TO NUTRIENT CONDITIONS. 
 
EPA AGREES THAT THE PHASE II TMDL RESULTS IN AN IMPROVED ANALYSIS AND MORE APPROPRIATE LCS.

"WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
AS OF JULY 2003, E. COLI IS NOW THE INDICATOR BACTERIUM (NOT FECAL COLIFORM) AND APPLIES TO WATERS DESIGNATED AS PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION CLASS A1, SECONDARY CONTACT CLASS 2, OR CHILDREN'S RECREATIONAL CLASS A3 USES.  THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES' (IDNR) 2006 SECTION 305(B) ASSESSMENT REPORT (IDNR, 2007B) IDENTIFIED NINE SEGMENTS WITHIN THE CEDAR RIVER WATERSHED AS EITHER ""NOT SUPPORTING"" OR ""PARTIALLY SUPPORTING"" BECAUSE OF LEVELS OF INDICATOR BACTERIA THAT EXCEED THAT STATE CRITERIA.  THE APPLICABLE WQS FOR INDICATOR BACTERIA E. COLI ARE A SEASONAL GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126 CFU/100 ML AND A SINGLE MAXIMUM VALUE OF 235 CFU/100 ML (IOWA ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (IAC) CHAPTER 61.3(3)(1)).  THESE WQS ARE APPLIED TO SURFACE WATER DURING THE RECREATION SEASON, WHICH IS FROM MARCH 15 TO NOVEMBER 15.  ALL SEGMENTS ARE DESIGNATED FOR WARM WATER AQUATIC LIFE TYPE 1(CLASS B_(WW-1)), AND FISH CONSUMPTION HUMAN HEALTH (HH).  SEGMENT 02-CED-0030_2 IS ALSO DESIGNATED FOR DRINKING WATER SUPPLY (CLASS C), AND SEGMENT 02-CED-0020_2, IS ALSO DESIGNATED AS A HIGH QUALITY WATER (CLASS HQR).

FOR THE CEDAR RIVER TMDL, THE LOAD CAPACITY GOAL IS DERIVED FROM THE NITRATE-N DRINKING WATER STANDARD, ADJUSTED WITH A 5% MARGIN OF SAFETY .  THIS MAKES THE IN-STREAM CONCENTRATION FOR ALL FLOWS AT OR BELOW 9.5 MG/L NITRATE-N, WITH NO EXCEEDANCES WITHIN THE 1.6MILE IMPAIRED SEGMENT.  THE ANNUAL NITRATE LOAD WAS ESTABLISHED USING THE WATER QUALITY SIMULATION PROGRAM (WASP) AND DIFFUSION ANNALOGY SURFACE WATER FLOW (DAFLOW) MODELING CONDUCTED WITH DAILY TIE STEPS.  FURTHER, THE TMDL IS ALSO EXPRESSED AS A LOAD DURATION CURVE BASED ON FLOW RECORDS FROM THE USGS GAGE 05464500 (CEDAR RIVER AT CEDAR RAPIDS, IA) AND IN-STREAM NITRATE MEASUREMENTS TAKEN AT CEDAR RAPIDS.  EXCLUDING WILDLIFE, ATMOSPHERIC DEPOSITION, AND POINT SOURCES, THE RELATIVE DECREASE TO EACH REMAINING NITROGEN INPUT IS 37%.  THIS REDUCTION IN NITROGEN LOADING SHOULD RESULT IN ATTAINMENT OF APPLICABLE DRINKING WATER STANDARDS.  THE CEDAR RIVER NITRATE TMDL LOAD REDUCTIONS ARE DESIGNED TO RELIABLY MEET THE DRINKING WATER STANDARD FOR NITRATE DIRECTLY, WITH AN EXPLICIT MARGIN OF SAFETY OF 5%.  NO SURROGATE MEASURE IS TARGETED.  REDUCTION ARE REQUIRED FOR NON-POINT SOURCE LOADS SUCH AS RUNOFF FROM FEEDLOTS AND PASTURE LANDS, MANURE APPLIED TO CROPLAND AND PASTURE THAT ARE TRANSPORTED BY PERCEPTION EVENTS AND THOSE THAT ARE RELATIVELY CONSTANT SUCH AS CATTLE IN STREAMS AND FAILED SEPTIC TANKS.  TO ACHIEVE THE STANDARD, THERE MUST BE 35% REDUCTION IN NITRATE-N LOADS DELIVERED BY SURFACE RUNOFF.  THE LOAD ALLOCATIONS AND MARGIN OF SAFETY DO NOT EXCEED THE LOAD CAPACITY.  NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION IS THE GREATEST CONTRIBUTOR OF NITRATE TO THE CEDAR RIVER. FOR THE GREATEST BENEFIT, WETLANDS, CRP, AND OTHER BMPS SHOULD BE INSTALLED AT LOCATIONS THAT HAVE THE GREATEST ABILITY TO INFLUENCE BOTH NITRATE AND WATER FLOW.  THE LOAD ALLOCATIONS FOR THE TOTAL NITROGEN NEEDED TO RECEIVE A 35% REDUCTION IN NITRATE-N AT THE IMPAIRED SITE ARE LISTED ON TABLE 17 IN THE TMDL.  THE DAILY LOAD IS REPRESENTED BY THE LOAD DURATION CURVES PRESENTED IN THE TMDL WHICH APPLY AT THE ACTUAL FLOW AT ANY GIVEN DAY.

"WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
THE POLLUTANT CAUSING THE WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENT IS ATRAZINE.  DESIGNATED USES FOR CEDAR LAKE ARE AQUATIC LIFE (CLASS B[LW]), HUMAN HEALTH (CLASS HH), AND DRINK WATER SUPPLY (CLASS C).  THE ATRAZINE LIMIT FOR CLASS C WATERS IS LISTED AS THE EPA DRINKING WATER MAXIMUM CONTAMINANT LEVEL (MCL), WHICH IS 3 UG/L.  IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (IDNR) INTERPRETS THIS LIMIT AS A MOVING ANNUAL AVERAGE TO ASSESS CONTAMINANT LEVELS IN DRINKING WATER SUPPLY LAKES.  EXCESS ATRAZINE LOADING HAS IMPAIRED THE POTABLE WATER SOURCE WATER QUALITY CRITERIA, 567 IOWA ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (IAC) 61.3(3)C(2) STATES FOR CLASS C WATERS:  ""ALL SUBSTANCES TOXIC OR DETRIMENTAL TO HUMANS OR DETRIMENTAL TO TREATMENT PROCESS SHALL BE LIMITED TO NONTOXIC OR NONDETRIMENTAL CONCENTRATIONS IN THE SURFACE WATER.""

ALTHOUGH IMPAIRED FOR ALGAE AND TURBIDITY, PHOSPHORUS IS THE PRINCIPAL NUTRIENT TARGET BECAUSE OF BLUE-GREEN ALGAE'S ABILITY TO FIX ATMOSPHERIC NITROGEN AND THE OVERABUNDANCE OF PHOSPHORUS INPUTS.  ONLY NONPOINT SOURCES INFLUENCE THE TP AND SEDIMENT LOADING.  CARLSON'S TSI SCORES WERE USED TO DEFINE AN ESTABISHED LINKAGE BETWEEN TP, CHLOROPHYLL, AND WATER TRANSPARENCY AS BASED ON REFERENCE LAKES. THE VOLLENWEIDER 1982 COMBINED OECD MODEL WAS USED TO RELATE TP LOADING TO GROWING SEASON IN-LAKE CONCENTRATIONS.  THE EXISTING LOAD IS EST AT 2,157LBS/Y, WHICH INCLUDES 2,136 FROM EXTERNAL NONPOINT SOURCES AND INTERNAL LOADING, AND 21LBS/Y FOR ATMOSHPHERIC DEPOSITION.  TURBIDITY IS CAUSED BY ALGAL CONDITIONS AND A NON-ALGAL SEDIMENT LOAD OF 1,070T/Y DELIVERED TO THE LAKE.  THE CURRENT SEDIMENT DELIVERY WAS DETERMINEED USING RUSLE AND 2005 LAND USES.  THE SEDIMENT LOADING IS 171 T/Y AND WILL BE USED ON THE LITTLEFIELD LAKE TMDL FOR TURBIDITY AND THE TP LOADING IS 925LBS/Y AND WILL BE USED ON THE LITTLEFIELD LAKE'A TMDL FOR ALGAE.  SEE TMDL FOR FURTHER INFORMATION.

ALL IMPAIRMENTS ARE THE RESULT OF PATHOGEN INDICATOR, E. COLI, THE POLLUTANT FOR THIS STREAM. ATTAINMENT OF WATER QUALITY STANDARDS WILL BE MET WHEN THE CRITERIA FOR CLASS A1 USE, WHICH IS EQUAL TO CLASS A3 CRITERIA, IS MET AND FULLY SUPPORT DESIGNATED USES AT ALL THREE DUCK CREEK LOCATIONS. THE USE ATTAINABILITY ANALYSIS PROPOSED THAT SECONDARY CONTACT RECREATION (CLASS A2) BE ESTABLISHED FOR A PORTION OF THE UPSTREAM SEGMENT. A MORE STRINGENT CRITERION IS APPLIED TO THIS UPSTREAM SEGMENT AS WELL. THE MORE STRINGENT CRITERION IS DUE TO SHORT TRAVEL TIME TO THE CLASS A3 USE REACH THAT DOES NOT ALLOW SIGNIFICANT DIE-OFF OF E. COLI. THIS ASSUMPTION PROVIDES PARTIAL BASIS FOR THE IMPLICIT MARGIN OF SAFETY.    
  
TABLE 3-2 OF THE TMDL QUOTES APPLICABLE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS FROM CHAPTER 61 OF THE IOWA ADMINISTRATIVE CODE FOR IMPAIRMENTS TO PRIMARY CONTACT AND CHILDREN'S RECREATION. WQS STATES THAT MAXIMUM DAILY LOADS FOR   
E. COLI CONCENTRATIONS ARE BASED ON A SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM CRITERION OF 235 CFU/100 ML; ALL FACILITIES OPERATING UNDER A NATIONAL POLLUTANT DISCHARGE ELIMINATION SYSTEM PERMIT MUST MEET THE 30-DAY GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126 CFU/100 ML.          
  
THE TMDL STATES THAT PRIMARY BENEFITS OF THIS WATERSHED INCLUDE RECREATION, AQUATIC AND RIPARIAN WILDLIFE HABITAT, AESTHETIC QUALITIES AND STORM DRAINAGE. HUMANS, SPECIFICALLY CHILDREN, ARE KNOWN TO RECREATE REGULARLY IN AND NEAR THE STREAM. ALL 303(D) LIST DESIGNATED USES ARE IMPAIRED DUE TO THE E. COLI POLLUTANT.       
  
APPENDIX G OF THE TMDL CONTAINS EXCERPTS FROM 305(B) ASSESSMENTS RELEVANT TO THE BACTERIA IMPAIRMENTS ON DUCK CREEK. THE ENTIRE ASSESSMENT IS AVAILABLE ON THE FOLLOWING WEB ADDRESS: HTTP://PROGRAMS.IOWADNR.GOV/ADBNET/INDEX.ASPX. 
  
A LOAD DURATION CURVE USING E. COLI CONCENTRATIONS AND MEAN DAILY FLOWS WERE USED TO CALCULATE THE LOADING CAPACITY ON A DAILY BASIS. THE LDC APPROACH INVOLVES DEVELOPING FLOW DURATION CURVES THAT REPRESENT THE PERCENT OF MEAN DAILY FLOWS THAT EQUAL OR EXCEED A GIVE FLOW VALUE. DURATION CURVES ARE CATEGORIZED INTO FIVE HYDROLOGIC CONDITIONS: HIGH, MOIST, MID-RANGE, DRY AND LOW. THE LDC IN THIS TMDL REPRESENTS THE LC ACROSS A RANGE OF FLOW CONDITIONS.

ALL IMPAIRMENTS ARE THE RESULT OF PATHOGEN INDICATOR, E. COLI, THE POLLUTANT FOR THIS STREAM. ATTAINMENT OF WATER QUALITY STANDARDS WILL BE MET WHEN THE CRITERIA FOR CLASS A1 USE, WHICH IS EQUAL TO CLASS A3 CRITERIA, IS MET AND FULLY SUPPORT DESIGNATED USES AT ALL THREE DUCK CREEK LOCATIONS. THE USE ATTAINABILITY ANALYSIS PROPOSED THAT SECONDARY CONTACT RECREATION (CLASS A2) BE ESTABLISHED FOR A PORTION OF THE UPSTREAM SEGMENT. A MORE STRINGENT CRITERION IS APPLIED TO THIS UPSTREAM SEGMENT AS WELL. THE MORE STRINGENT CRITERION IS DUE TO SHORT TRAVEL TIME TO THE CLASS A3 USE REACH THAT DOES NOT ALLOW SIGNIFICANT DIE-OFF OF E. COLI. THIS ASSUMPTION PROVIDES PARTIAL BASIS FOR THE IMPLICIT MARGIN OF SAFETY.

TABLE 3-2 OF THE TMDL QUOTES APPLICABLE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS FROM CHAPTER 61 OF THE IOWA ADMINISTRATIVE CODE FOR IMPAIRMENTS TO PRIMARY CONTACT AND CHILDREN'S RECREATION. WQS STATES THAT MAXIMUM DAILY LOADS FOR   
E. COLI CONCENTRATIONS ARE BASED ON A SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM CRITERION OF 235 CFU/100 ML; ALL FACILITIES OPERATING UNDER A NATIONAL POLLUTANT DISCHARGE ELIMINATION SYSTEM PERMIT MUST MEET THE 30-DAY GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126 CFU/100 ML.          
  
THE TMDL STATES THAT PRIMARY BENEFITS OF THIS WATERSHED INCLUDE RECREATION, AQUATIC AND RIPARIAN WILDLIFE HABITAT, AESTHETIC QUALITIES AND STORM DRAINAGE. HUMANS, SPECIFICALLY CHILDREN, ARE KNOWN TO RECREATE REGULARLY IN AND NEAR THE STREAM. ALL 303(D) LIST DESIGNATED USES ARE IMPAIRED DUE TO THE E. COLI POLLUTANT.       
  
APPENDIX G OF THE TMDL CONTAINS EXCERPTS FROM 305(B) ASSESSMENTS RELEVANT TO THE BACTERIA IMPAIRMENTS ON DUCK CREEK. THE ENTIRE ASSESSMENT IS AVAILABLE ON THE FOLLOWING WEB ADDRESS: HTTP://PROGRAMS.IOWADNR.GOV/ADBNET/INDEX.ASPX. 
  
A LOAD DURATION CURVE USING E. COLI CONCENTRATIONS AND MEAN DAILY FLOWS WERE USED TO CALCULATE THE LOADING CAPACITY ON A DAILY BASIS. THE LDC APPROACH INVOLVES DEVELOPING FLOW DURATION CURVES THAT REPRESENT THE PERCENT OF MEAN DAILY FLOWS THAT EQUAL OR EXCEED A GIVE FLOW VALUE. DURATION CURVES ARE CATEGORIZED INTO FIVE HYDROLOGIC CONDITIONS: HIGH, MOIST, MID-RANGE, DRY AND LOW. THE LDC IN THIS TMDL REPRESENTS THE LC ACROSS A RANGE OF FLOW CONDITIONS.

"Water Quality Standards Attainment:

Kent Park Lake is a significant publicly owned lake, and it is protected for the following designated uses: 

 
• Primary contact recreation – Class A1: Waters in which recreational or other uses may result in prolonged and direct contact with the water, involving considerable risk of ingesting water in quantities sufficient to pose a health hazard. Such activities would include, but not be limited to, swimming, diving, water skiing and water contact recreational canoeing.
 
• Aquatic life – Class B(LW): Man-made and natural impoundments with hydraulic retention times and other physical and chemical characteristics suitable to maintain a balanced community normally associated with lake-like conditions. 
 
• Fish consumption – Class HH: Waters in which fish are routinely harvested for human consumption or waters both designated as a drinking water supply and in which fish are routinely harvested for human consumption. 
 
The state of Iowa Water Quality Standards are published in the Iowa Administrative Code, Environmental Protection Rule 567, Chapter 61. Although the state of Iowa does not have numeric criteria for sediment, nutrients or algae (chlorophyll-a), narrative water quality criteria are in the WQS. Chapter 61.3(2) of the WQS contains the general water quality criteria, which are applicable to all surface waters. These narrative criteria include that waters shall be free from materials attributable to wastewater discharges or agricultural practices producing objectionable color, odor or other aesthetically objectionable conditions. 
 

The WQS - numeric criterion - for pH requires that pH shall not be less than 6.5 nor greater than 9.0 for the water body's designated Class A1 or Class B(LW) uses.
 

Kent Park Lake is impaired because the aquatic life use and primary contact recreation use are not fully supported due to excursions of the narrative WQS - free from aesthetically objectionable conditions, and excursions of the numeric criterion for pH. Excessive algal blooms cause the impairments and are the result of phosphorus loads to the lake.

 
The impairments caused by excessive algae are addressed numerically by the loading capacity which limits the total phosphorus load to the lake. The target is based on relationships between TSI values for chlorophyll-a, total phosphorus, Secchi depth and modeled water quality results. The TP loading capacity for Kent Park Lake is established at 270.2 pounds per year (3.0 pounds per day). To meet the target loads, an overall reduction of 54.6 percent of the existing TP load (595.2 lb/year) is required. The current TP load and necessary load reduction were simulated using the Spreadsheet Tool for Estimating Pollutant Loads model and the in-lake water quality responses were simulated using the Bathtub model. The chlorophyll-a TSI response / target of 63 complies with the narrative criteria free from aesthetically objectionable conditions, and considers and protects the Class A1, Class B(LW) and Class HH designated uses of Kent Park Lake.
 
The TMDL target is for the median growing season chlorophyll-a Carlson’s TSI not to exceed 63 in two consecutive listing cycles which corresponds to a chlorophyll-a concentration of 27 micrograms per liter or less. The IDNR established target will ensure long-term protection to fully support primary contact recreation. All other uses will be protected at the stated total phosphorus and chlorophyll-a targets. For Bathtub modeling purposes, the lake was divided into two segments (see Figure D-1 of Appendix D, and Figure E-1 of Appendix E of the TMDL document). The Kent Park Lake TMDL document’s current model targeting approach uses surface area/mean depth with a single point of context in the lake. It is the EPA’s "

THE NARRATIVE CRITERIA REQUIRE THAT WATER BE FREE FROM AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS, ACCORDING TO THE IOWA ADMINISTRATIVE CODE 567, CHAPTER 61 WATER QUALITY STANDARDS. TO INTERPRET THESE WQS CRITERIA, CHLOROPHYLL A TROPHIC STATE INDEX OF 65 (OR CHLOROPHYLL A = 34 MICROGRAMS PER LITER) AND SECCHI DEPTH OF 0.7 METERS ARE USED AS THE WQS TARGETS FOR ALGAE AND TURBIDITY, RESPECTIVELY.

PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION PERIOD:  
MARCH 15 TO NOVEMBER 15  
  
THE 2008 305(B) WATER QUALITY ASSESSMENT IS PROVIDED IN APPENDIX F OF THE TMDL. FOR BIG CREEK LAKE, THE CLASS A1 USE WAS ASSESSED AS NOT SUPPORTED BASED ON THE RESULTS OF MONITORING FOR INDICATOR BACTERIA (E. COLI). ACCORDING TO THE IDNR'S ASSESSMENT AND IMPAIRED LISTING METHODOLOGY, IF MONITORING SHOWS THAT GREATER THAN TEN PERCENT OF SAMPLES EXCEED THE SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM, A LAKE IS PARTIALLY SUPPORTED FOR CLASS A1 USE AND IS IMPAIRED.   
  
THE WQS EXCEEDANCES, COMPLIANCE TARGETS AND FLOW AND LOAD DURATION CURVES WERE USED TO SET POLLUTANT ALLOCATIONS. THE MONITORED E. COLI CONCENTRATIONS WERE MULTIPLIED BY THE DAILY FLOW TO GET THE DAILY LOADS THAT ARE PLOTTED WITH THE LOAD DURATION CURVE. THE MAXIMUM ALLOWABLE LOAD FOR A RECURRENCE PERCENTAGE IS THE FLOW MULTIPLIED BY THE GEOMETRIC MEAN AND SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM CURVES.  THE SOIL AND WATER ASSESSMENT TOOL AND THE EPA BACTERIA INDICATOR TOOL WERE ALSO USED TO DEVELOP TARGETS FOR THIS TMDL. THE SOIL AND WATER ASSESSMENT TOOL IS A WATERSHED MODEL USED TO SIMULATE HYDROLOGY, WASHOFF AND TRANSPORT OF BACTERIA, WHILE THE EPA BACTERIA INDICATOR TOOL IS A BACTERIA SOURCE EVALUATION SPREADSHEET. 
  
THE LOADING CAPACITY WAS CALCULATED BY MULTIPLYING THE MIDPOINT FLOW AND E. COLI CRITERIA CONCENTRATIONS. AT MID-RANGE, 40-60 PERCENT RECURRENCE INTERVAL RANGE, THE LOADING CAPACITY AT MID RANGE IS 20 CFS, 33 CFS AND 12 CFS FOR MIDPOINT, MAXIMUM AND MINIMUM FLOW RANGE, RESPECTIVELY. THE LOADING CAPACITY TARGETS FOR TMDL ARE AT MID-RANGE, 6.2E+10 ORGS/DAY FOR THE GEOMETRIC MEAN AND 1.2E+11 ORGS/DAY FOR THE SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM.

"WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
AS OF JULY 2003, E. COLI IS NOW THE INDICATOR BACTERIUM (NOT FECAL COLIFORM) AND APPLIES TO WATERS DESIGNATED AS PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION CLASS A1, SECONDARY CONTACT CLASS 2, OR CHILDREN'S RECREATIONAL CLASS A3 USES.  THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES' (IDNR) 2006 SECTION 305(B) ASSESSMENT REPORT (IDNR, 2007B) IDENTIFIED NINE SEGMENTS WITHIN THE CEDAR RIVER WATERSHED AS EITHER ""NOT SUPPORTING"" OR ""PARTIALLY SUPPORTING"" BECAUSE OF LEVELS OF INDICATOR BACTERIA THAT EXCEED THAT STATE CRITERIA.  THE APPLICABLE WQS FOR INDICATOR BACTERIA E. COLI ARE A SEASONAL GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126 CFU/100 ML AND A SINGLE MAXIMUM VALUE OF 235 CFU/100 ML (IOWA ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (IAC) CHAPTER 61.3(3)(1)).  THESE WQS ARE APPLIED TO SURFACE WATER DURING THE RECREATION SEASON, WHICH IS FROM MARCH 15 TO NOVEMBER 15.  ALL SEGMENTS ARE DESIGNATED FOR WARM WATER AQUATIC LIFE TYPE 1(CLASS B_(WW-1)), AND FISH CONSUMPTION HUMAN HEALTH (HH).  SEGMENT 02-CED-0030_2 IS ALSO DESIGNATED FOR DRINKING WATER SUPPLY (CLASS C), AND SEGMENT 02-CED-0020_2, IS ALSO DESIGNATED AS A HIGH QUALITY WATER (CLASS HQR).

THIS TMDL WILL RESULT IN A 75% REDUCTION IN TOTAL PHOSPHORUS LOADING AND ATTAINMENT OF APPLICABLE WQS. THE TOTAL PHOSPHORUS LOADING CAPACITY VARIES WITH PROPORTION OF THE ORGIN OF THE LOAD.   AS AN EXAMPLE, THE NUMBERS USED IN THIS DOCUMENT ARE BASED ON INTERNAL LOADING OF 0 POUNDS AND EXTERNAL LOADING 1,070 POUNDS PER YEAR.  THIS MAKES THE WLA 810, THE LA 260 AND THE REQUIRED LOAD REDUCTION PER YEAR 2,340 POUNDS PER YEAR.

THE POLLUTANT LOAD FOR CHLORDANE IS SET A ZERO.  AS THE CHLORDANE ALREADY IN THE SYSTEM DEGRADES ORIS REMOVED THROUGH NATURAL PORCESSES THE WATERBODY SHOULD REACH ATTAINMENT OF APPLICABLE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS.  IN 2002 FISH TISSUE MONITORING COMPOSITE CHANNEL CATFISH TISSUES SHOWED CONCENTRATIONS OF 0.78 MG/KG OF TECHNICAL CHLORDANE.  THIS TMDL SHOULD RESULT IN A 100% REDUCTION OF CHLORDANE IN FISH TISSUE. THE MARGIN OF SAFETY FOR CHLORDANE IS IMPLICIT IN THAT TWO CONSECUTIVE FISH TISSUE SAMPLES MUST TEST BELOW THE FDA ACTION LEVEL OF 0.3MG/KG IN FISH TISSUE TO MEET THE TMDL ENDPOINT.

THIS TMDL WILL RESULT IN A 75% REDUCTION IN TOTAL PHOSPHORUS LOADING AND ATTAINMENT OF APPLICABLE WQS. THE TOTAL PHOSPHORUS LOADING CAPACITY VARIES WITH PROPORTION OF THE ORGIN OF THE LOAD.   AS AN EXAMPLE, THE NUMBERS USED IN THIS DOCUMENT ARE BASED ON INTERNAL LOADING OF 0 POUNDS AND EXTERNAL LOADING 1,070 POUNDS PER YEAR.  THIS MAKES THE WLA 810, THE LA 260 AND THE REQUIRED LOAD REDUCTION PER YEAR 2,340 POUNDS PER YEAR.

ALL IMPAIRMENTS ARE THE RESULT OF PATHOGEN INDICATOR, E. COLI, THE POLLUTANT FOR THIS STREAM. ATTAINMENT OF WATER QUALITY STANDARDS WILL BE MET WHEN THE CRITERIA FOR CLASS A1 USE, WHICH IS EQUAL TO CLASS A3 CRITERIA, IS MET AND FULLY SUPPORT DESIGNATED USES AT ALL THREE DUCK CREEK LOCATIONS. THE USE ATTAINABILITY ANALYSIS PROPOSED THAT SECONDARY CONTACT RECREATION (CLASS A2) BE ESTABLISHED FOR A PORTION OF THE UPSTREAM SEGMENT. A MORE STRINGENT CRITERION IS APPLIED TO THIS UPSTREAM SEGMENT AS WELL. THE MORE STRINGENT CRITERION IS DUE TO SHORT TRAVEL TIME TO THE CLASS A3 USE REACH THAT DOES NOT ALLOW SIGNIFICANT DIE-OFF OF E. COLI. THIS ASSUMPTION PROVIDES PARTIAL BASIS FOR THE IMPLICIT MARGIN OF SAFETY.    
  
TABLE 3-2 OF THE TMDL QUOTES APPLICABLE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS FROM CHAPTER 61 OF THE IOWA ADMINISTRATIVE CODE FOR IMPAIRMENTS TO PRIMARY CONTACT AND CHILDREN'S RECREATION. WQS STATES THAT MAXIMUM DAILY LOADS FOR   
E. COLI CONCENTRATIONS ARE BASED ON A SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM CRITERION OF 235 CFU/100 ML; ALL FACILITIES OPERATING UNDER A NATIONAL POLLUTANT DISCHARGE ELIMINATION SYSTEM PERMIT MUST MEET THE 30-DAY GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126 CFU/100 ML.          
  
THE TMDL STATES THAT PRIMARY BENEFITS OF THIS WATERSHED INCLUDE RECREATION, AQUATIC AND RIPARIAN WILDLIFE HABITAT, AESTHETIC QUALITIES AND STORM DRAINAGE. HUMANS, SPECIFICALLY CHILDREN, ARE KNOWN TO RECREATE REGULARLY IN AND NEAR THE STREAM. ALL 303(D) LIST DESIGNATED USES ARE IMPAIRED DUE TO THE E. COLI POLLUTANT.       
  
APPENDIX G OF THE TMDL CONTAINS EXCERPTS FROM 305(B) ASSESSMENTS RELEVANT TO THE BACTERIA IMPAIRMENTS ON DUCK CREEK. THE ENTIRE ASSESSMENT IS AVAILABLE ON THE FOLLOWING WEB ADDRESS: HTTP://PROGRAMS.IOWADNR.GOV/ADBNET/INDEX.ASPX. 
  
A LOAD DURATION CURVE USING E. COLI CONCENTRATIONS AND MEAN DAILY FLOWS WERE USED TO CALCULATE THE LOADING CAPACITY ON A DAILY BASIS. THE LDC APPROACH INVOLVES DEVELOPING FLOW DURATION CURVES THAT REPRESENT THE PERCENT OF MEAN DAILY FLOWS THAT EQUAL OR EXCEED A GIVE FLOW VALUE. DURATION CURVES ARE CATEGORIZED INTO FIVE HYDROLOGIC CONDITIONS: HIGH, MOIST, MID-RANGE, DRY AND LOW. THE LDC IN THIS TMDL REPRESENTS THE LC ACROSS A RANGE OF FLOW CONDITIONS.

ALL IMPAIRMENTS ARE THE RESULT OF PATHOGEN INDICATOR, E. COLI, THE POLLUTANT FOR THIS STREAM. ATTAINMENT OF WATER QUALITY STANDARDS WILL BE MET WHEN THE CRITERIA FOR CLASS A1 USE, WHICH IS EQUAL TO CLASS A3 CRITERIA, IS MET AND FULLY SUPPORT DESIGNATED USES AT ALL THREE DUCK CREEK LOCATIONS. THE USE ATTAINABILITY ANALYSIS PROPOSED THAT SECONDARY CONTACT RECREATION (CLASS A2) BE ESTABLISHED FOR A PORTION OF THE UPSTREAM SEGMENT. A MORE STRINGENT CRITERION IS APPLIED TO THIS UPSTREAM SEGMENT AS WELL. THE MORE STRINGENT CRITERION IS DUE TO SHORT TRAVEL TIME TO THE CLASS A3 USE REACH THAT DOES NOT ALLOW SIGNIFICANT DIE-OFF OF E. COLI. THIS ASSUMPTION PROVIDES PARTIAL BASIS FOR THE IMPLICIT MARGIN OF SAFETY.

"WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
AS OF JULY 2003, E. COLI IS NOW THE INDICATOR BACTERIUM (NOT FECAL COLIFORM) AND APPLIES TO WATERS DESIGNATED AS PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION CLASS A1, SECONDARY CONTACT CLASS 2, OR CHILDREN'S RECREATIONAL CLASS A3 USES.  THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES' (IDNR) 2006 SECTION 305(B) ASSESSMENT REPORT (IDNR, 2007B) IDENTIFIED NINE SEGMENTS WITHIN THE CEDAR RIVER WATERSHED AS EITHER ""NOT SUPPORTING"" OR ""PARTIALLY SUPPORTING"" BECAUSE OF LEVELS OF INDICATOR BACTERIA THAT EXCEED THAT STATE CRITERIA.  THE APPLICABLE WQS FOR INDICATOR BACTERIA E. COLI ARE A SEASONAL GEOMETRIC MEAN OF 126 CFU/100 ML AND A SINGLE MAXIMUM VALUE OF 235 CFU/100 ML (IOWA ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (IAC) CHAPTER 61.3(3)(1)).  THESE WQS ARE APPLIED TO SURFACE WATER DURING THE RECREATION SEASON, WHICH IS FROM MARCH 15 TO NOVEMBER 15.  ALL SEGMENTS ARE DESIGNATED FOR WARM WATER AQUATIC LIFE TYPE 1(CLASS B_(WW-1)), AND FISH CONSUMPTION HUMAN HEALTH (HH).  SEGMENT 02-CED-0030_2 IS ALSO DESIGNATED FOR DRINKING WATER SUPPLY (CLASS C), AND SEGMENT 02-CED-0020_2, IS ALSO DESIGNATED AS A HIGH QUALITY WATER (CLASS HQR).

"WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
WATER QUALITY TARGETS FOR VENTURA MARSH WERE BASED ON IOWA'S GENERAL USE NARRATIVE (567 IAC 61.3(2)C AND E) THAT STATES:
 

""WATERS SHALL BE FROM MATERIALS ATTRIBUTABLE TO WASTEWATER DISCHARGES OR AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES PRODUCING OBJECTIONABLE COLOR, ODOR, OR OTHER AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS,""
""WATERS SHALL BE FREE FROM SUBSTANCES, ATTRIBUTABLE TO WASTEWATER DISCHARGES OR AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, IN QUANTITIES WHICH WOULD PRODUCE UNDESIRABLE OR NUISANCE AQUATIC LIFE."" 
 
VENTURA MARSH WAS LISTED IMPAIRED IN ACCORDANCE TO THE NARRATIVE CRITERIA RELATING EXCESSIVE TURBIDITY TO ALGAL BIOMASS AND RESUSPENSION OF BOTTOM SEDIMENTS(FROM COMMON CARP) THAT NEGATIVELY IMPACT WATER CLARITY, ZOOPLANKTON COMPOSITION, AND MACROPHYTE DISTRIBUTION WITHIN THE WETLAND.  A STUDY BY SCHRAGE AND DOWNING (2004) FOUND A CORRELATION BETWEEN THE FISH REMOVAL AND INCREASED WATER CLARITY DEMONSTRATED THROUGH A REDUCTION OF SUSPENDED SEDIMENTS AND PHYTOPLANKTON BIOMASS.  THIS STUDY ALSO CONCLUDED THAT THE REMOVAL OF THE BIOTURBATING FISH POPULATION WILL LEAD TO THE IMPROVEMENT OF WATER QUALITY AND AQUATIC LIFE FUNCTIONS IN VENTURA MARSH BY IMPROVING LIGHT TRANSMISSION TO THE ENTIRE WATERSHED.  THIS WOULD RESULT IN THE INCREASE OF MACROPHYTE GROWTH THROUGH THE REDUCTION OF SEDIMENT RESUSPENSION.  INCREASED LEVELS OF MACROPHYTES WILL BENEFIT THE ZOOPLANKTON POPULATION, THUS INCREASING GRAZING ACTIVITIES AND LOWER PHYTOPLANKTON LEVELS.  IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY CONDUCTED THE CLEAR LAKE DIAGNOSTIC AND FEASIBILITY REPORT THAT NAMED VENTURA MARSH A SIGNIFICANT SOURCE FOR NUTRIENTS.  IN 2006, THE CLEAR LAKE TMDL IDENTIFIED VENTURA MARSH AS A MAJOR SOURCE OF PHOSPHORUS TO THE LAKE.  BOTH STUDIES DISCUSSED THE ADVERSE IMPACTS OF RESUSPENSION OF BOTTOM SEDIMENTS BY BIOTURBATING CARP ON WATER QUALITY IN VENTURA MARSH AND CLEAR LAKE.    
 
TMDL TARGETS FOR THIS TMDL ARE 2.0 MG/L FOR ISS AND 68.0 UG/L FOR TP.  REDUCTIONS OF 93 PERCENT AND 82 PERCENT ARE NECESSARY TO ACHIEVE INDICATED TARGETS.  TMDL TARGETS FOR ISS, TP AND CHLOROPHYLL A WERE DEVELOPED USING CARLSON'S TROPHIC STATUS INDEX (TSI).  CARLSON'S TSI WAS USED TO LINK THE CONCENTRATION OF TP TO THE QUANTITY OF ALGAE AND TURBIDITY IN THE SYSTEM.  THE CHLOROPHYLL A TARGET FOR THIS TMDL IS 33.3 UG/L.  A CARLSON'S TSI VALUE OF 65 TP IS DESIRED OF VENTURA MARSH.  THIS VALUE REPRESENTS WATER BODIES WITH MACROPHYTES AND CENTRACHIDS (SUNFISH).  THE TARGET FOR TRANSPARENCY IS 0.7 M.  THE LA 617 TONS/YEAR, OR 3.6 TONS/DAY FOR ISS AND 41,276 LBS/YR, OR 241 LBS/DAY TP.    
 
BENEFICIAL USES FOR VENTURA MARSH ARE AQUATIC LIFE (CLASS B (LW)) AND HUMAN HEALTH (HH). 
 
AQUATIC LIFE USE IS THE ONLY IMPAIRED USE DUE TO ALGAE AND TURBIDITY. 
 
ALL INFORMATION IS BASED ON A STUDY CONDUCTED BY IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY IN 1999 AND 2000 AS PART OF THE CLEAR LAKE DIAGNOSTIC AND FEASIBILITY STUDY.

TMDL TARGETS FOR THIS TMDL ARE 2.0 MG/L FOR ISS AND 68.0 UG/L FOR TP.  REDUCTIONS OF 93 PERCENT AND 82 PERCENT ARE NECESSARY TO ACHIEVE INDICATED TARGETS.  TMDL TARGETS FOR ISS, TP AND CHLOROPHYLL A WERE DEVELOPED USING CARLSON'S TROPHIC STATUS INDEX (TSI).  CARLSON'S TSI WAS USED TO LINK THE CONCENTRATION OF TP TO THE QUANTITY OF ALGAE AND TURBIDITY IN THE SYSTEM.  THE CHLOROPHYLL A TARGET FOR THIS TMDL IS 33.3 UG/L.  A CARLSON'S TSI VALUE OF 65 TP IS DESIRED OF VENTURA MARSH.  THIS VALUE REPRESENTS WATER BODIES WITH MACROPHYTES AND CENTRACHIDS (SUNFISH).  THE TARGET FOR TRANSPARENCY IS 0.7 M.  THE LA 617 TONS/YEAR, OR 3.6 TONS/DAY FOR ISS AND 41,276 LBS/YR, OR 241 LBS/DAY TP.    
 
BENEFICIAL USES FOR VENTURA MARSH ARE AQUATIC LIFE (CLASS B (LW)) AND HUMAN HEALTH (HH). 
 
AQUATIC LIFE USE IS THE ONLY IMPAIRED USE DUE TO ALGAE AND TURBIDITY. 
 
ALL INFORMATION IS BASED ON A STUDY CONDUCTED BY IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY IN 1999 AND 2000 AS PART OF THE CLEAR LAKE DIAGNOSTIC AND FEASIBILITY STUDY.

""WATERS SHALL BE FROM MATERIALS ATTRIBUTABLE TO WASTEWATER DISCHARGES OR AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES PRODUCING OBJECTIONABLE COLOR, ODOR, OR OTHER AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS,""
""WATERS SHALL BE FREE FROM SUBSTANCES, ATTRIBUTABLE TO WASTEWATER DISCHARGES OR AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, IN QUANTITIES WHICH WOULD PRODUCE UNDESIRABLE OR NUISANCE AQUATIC LIFE."" 
 
VENTURA MARSH WAS LISTED IMPAIRED IN ACCORDANCE TO THE NARRATIVE CRITERIA RELATING EXCESSIVE TURBIDITY TO ALGAL BIOMASS AND RESUSPENSION OF BOTTOM SEDIMENTS(FROM COMMON CARP) THAT NEGATIVELY IMPACT WATER CLARITY, ZOOPLANKTON COMPOSITION, AND MACROPHYTE DISTRIBUTION WITHIN THE WETLAND. ""WATERS SHALL BE FROM MATERIALS ATTRIBUTABLE TO WASTEWATER DISCHARGES OR AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES PRODUCING OBJECTIONABLE COLOR, ODOR, OR OTHER AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS,""
""WATERS SHALL BE FREE FROM SUBSTANCES, ATTRIBUTABLE TO WASTEWATER DISCHARGES OR AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, IN QUANTITIES WHICH WOULD PRODUCE UNDESIRABLE OR NUISANCE AQUATIC LIFE."" 
 
VENTURA MARSH WAS LISTED IMPAIRED IN ACCORDANCE TO THE NARRATIVE CRITERIA RELATING EXCESSIVE TURBIDITY TO ALGAL BIOMASS AND RESUSPENSION OF BOTTOM SEDIMENTS(FROM COMMON CARP) THAT NEGATIVELY IMPACT WATER CLARITY, ZOOPLANKTON COMPOSITION, AND MACROPHYTE DISTRIBUTION WITHIN THE WETLAND.  A STUDY BY SCHRAGE AND DOWNING (2004) FOUND A CORRELATION BETWEEN THE FISH REMOVAL AND INCREASED WATER CLARITY DEMONSTRATED THROUGH A REDUCTION OF SUSPENDED SEDIMENTS AND PHYTOPLANKTON BIOMASS.  THIS STUDY ALSO CONCLUDED THAT THE REMOVAL OF THE BIOTURBATING FISH POPULATION WILL LEAD TO THE IMPROVEMENT OF WATER QUALITY AND AQUATIC LIFE FUNCTIONS IN VENTURA MARSH BY IMPROVING LIGHT TRANSMISSION TO THE ENTIRE WATERSHED.  THIS WOULD RESULT IN THE INCREASE OF MACROPHYTE GROWTH THROUGH THE REDUCTION OF SEDIMENT RESUSPENSION.  INCREASED LEVELS OF MACROPHYTES WILL BENEFIT THE ZOOPLANKTON POPULATION, THUS INCREASING GRAZING ACTIVITIES AND LOWER PHYTOPLANKTON LEVELS.  IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY CONDUCTED THE CLEAR LAKE DIAGNOSTIC AND FEASIBILITY REPORT THAT NAMED VENTURA MARSH A SIGNIFICANT SOURCE FOR NUTRIENTS. GM MOS IS 6.2E+09 ORGS/DAY, SSM MOS IS 1.2E+10 ORGS/DAY.  
ALL ALLOCATIONS WERE TAKEN AT MID-RANGE RECURRENCE LEVEL OF 40-60%.

THE PHASE I TARGET FOR THIS TMDL IS AN AVERAGE WATER TRANSPARENCY LEVEL MEASURED BY SECCHI DEPTH GREATER THAN .7 METERS.  THIS TARGET IS EQUIVALENT TO A TSI VALUE OF 65 WHICH IS THE MINIMUM DEPTH CONSIDERED TO BE FULLY SUPPORTING/THREATENED FOR THE SECTION 305(B) USE SUPPORT CATEGORY.  THIS TARGET REQUIRES AN INCREASE IN TRANSPARENCY OF 14.3%. BASED ON ISU SAMPLING DATA FOR 2000-2004 THE CHLOROPHYLL AND TOTAL PHOSPHORUS TARGETS ARE BEING MET.  TURBIDITY LEVELS IN SPRING LAKE ARE CREATED BY AN EXISTING SEDIMENT LOAD OF 186 TONS RESUSPENDED IN THE LAKE.  THIS CALCULATED USING LAKE HYDROLOGY, MEASURED TSS AND DAM TRAPPING EFFICIENCY. THE BRUNE METHOD (BRUNE�S CURVE) WAS USED TO CALCULATE TRAP EFFICIENCY OF THE LAKE BASED ON VOLUME AND INFLOW.

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText:
"Water Quality Standards Attainment:


Little River Lake is a significant publicly owned lake, and it is protected for the following designated uses: 
 
• Primary contact recreation – Class A1: Waters in which recreational or other uses may result in prolonged and direct contact with the water, involving considerable risk of ingesting water in quantities sufficient to pose a health hazard. Such activities would include, but not be limited to, swimming, diving, water skiing and water contact recreational canoeing.
 
• Aquatic life – Class B(LW): Man-made and natural impoundments with hydraulic retention times and other physical and chemical characteristics suitable to maintain a balanced community normally associated with lake-like conditions. 
 
• Fish consumption – Class HH: Waters in which fish are routinely harvested for human consumption or waters both designated as a drinking water supply and in which fish are routinely harvested for human consumption. 
 
• Drinking water – Class C: Waters which are used as a raw water source of potable water supply.
 
The State of Iowa Water Quality Standards are published in the Iowa Administrative Code, Environmental Protection Rule 567, Chapter 61. Although the State of Iowa does not have numeric criteria for sediment, nutrients or algae (chlorophyll-a), narrative water quality criteria are applicable. Chapter 61.3(2) of the WQS contains the general water quality criteria, which are applicable to all surface waters. These narrative criteria include that waters shall be free from materials attributable to wastewater discharges or agricultural practices producing objectionable color, odor or other aesthetically objectionable conditions. 
 

Little River Lake is impaired because primary contact recreation and aquatic life uses are not fully supported due to excursions of the narrative WQS - free from aesthetically objectionable conditions. High levels of non-algal turbidity cause the impairment. This turbidity is the result of sediment loads from the watershed. Because sediment is laden with PHOSPHORUS, TOTAL, targeting a reduction of PHOSPHORUS, TOTAL will address turbidity and poor water clarity, and also reduce the potential for increased algal blooms as light limitation decreases. 
 
The impairment caused by non-algal turbidity is addressed numerically by the loading capacity which limits the PHOSPHORUS, TOTAL load to the lake. The target is based on relationships between trophic state index scores (for Secchi depth, chlorophyl-a and PHOSPHORUS, TOTAL) and modeled water quality results. The TP loading capacity for Little River Lake is established at 8,393 pounds per year (92 pounds per day). To meet the target loads, an overall reduction of 58.9 percent of the current TP load is required. The current TP load and necessary load reduction were simulated using the STEPL model; the in-lake water quality response was simulated using the BATHTUB model. The Secchi depth TSI response / target of 63 complies with the narrative criteria free from aesthetically objectionable conditions. The TP and chlorophyll-a concentrations and TSI values in Table 3-1 of the TMDL document represent in-lake water quality response and associated TP load reductions from the watershed necessary to obtain the Secchi depth TSI target and therefore, the narrative WQS. 

Numeric Target(s):

Such activities would include, but not be limited to, swimming, diving, water skiing and water contact recreational canoeing.
 
• Aquatic life – Class B(LW): Man-made and natural impou"

"Water Quality Standards Attainment:
The designated uses listed for Hannen Lake are Primary Contact Recreational Class A1, Aquatic Life Class B(LW) and Human Health Fish Consumption (HH). The specific water quality criteria for these designated uses are listed below and published in the Environmental Protection Rule 567, Chapter 61 water quality standards:
 
Subrule 61.3(5) for Class A1 water and pH states, ""The pH shall not be less than 6.5 nor greater than 9.0. The maximum change permitted as a result of a waste discharge shall not exceed 0.5 pH units.""
 
Subrule 61.3(5) 6(1) for Class B (LW) waters is referenced in Table 2 of the IA WQS (Ch.1, p.21). The minimum value at any time during every 24-hour period should be 5.0 milligrams per liter. The value of 5.0 mg/L applies only to the upper layer of stratification in lakes. 
 
Subrule 61.3(3) states, ""The waters which are designated as Class ""HH"" shall contain no substances in concentration which will make fish or shell-fish inedible due to undesirable tastes or cause a hazard to humans after consumption."" Specific toxic chemical criteria were also available.
 
Waters which are designated as Class HH shall contain no substances in concentrations which will make fish or shellfish inedible due to undesirable tastes or cause a hazard to humans after consumption.
 
The 2010 305(b) Report states that the Class A1 Primary Contact Recreation uses were assessed (monitored) as ""partially supported"" due to aesthetically objectionable conditions caused by algal turbidity and excursions to the Class A1 pH criterion. The Class B(LW) aquatic life uses are assessed as ""partially supported"" due to excursions of the Class B(LW) criterion for pH. Excursions to the Class B(LW) chronic criteria for ammonia suggest an additional potential impairment of the aquatic life uses. Fish consumption uses remain ""not assessed"" due to a lack of fish contaminant monitoring at this lake. Sources of data for this assessment include: 1) results of the statewide survey of Iowa lakes conducted from 2004 through 2007 by Iowa State University, 2) results of the statewide ambient lake monitoring program conducted from 2005 through 208 by University Hygienic Laboratory and 3) information from the IDNR Fisheries Bureau.
 
Algae and pH impairments are linked to the rapid growth of algae which results in the increase of algal photosynthesis. The increase of algal photosynthesis increases lake pH by removing carbon dioxide and shifting the carbonate system equilibrium. PHOSPHORUS, TOTAL is the limiting nutrient for algal growth. The target for TP concentration is a TSI of less than 63. The TMDL document recognizes Carlson's TSI values of less than 63 for chlorophyll a and less than 61 for Secchi depth to achieve supporting water quality within the watershed.

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText: WQS will be attained in the NSBV when less than 10% of samples exceed the SSM criterion of 235 orgs/100 mL during the recreational season of March 15 – November 15. This TMDL will meet Water Quality Standards.

The impairment caused by excessive algae is addressed numerically by the loading capacity which limits the total phosphorus load to the lake. The target is based on relationships between TSI values for chlorophyll-a, total phosphorus, Secchi depth and modeled water quality results. The TP loading capacity for Lake Iowa is established at 436.1 pounds per year (4.8 pounds per day). To meet the target loads, an overall reduction of 79 percent of the existing TP load (2,110 lb/year) is required. The current TP load and necessary load reduction were simulated using the Spreadsheet Tool for Estimating Pollutant Loads model and the in-lake water quality responses were simulated using the Bathtub model. The chlorophyll-a TSI response / target of 63 complies with the narrative criteria free from aesthetically objectionable conditions, and considers and protects the Class A1, Class B(LW) and Class HH designated uses of Lake Iowa. The IDNR-established targets will ensure long-term protection to fully support primary contact recreation. All other uses will be protected at the stated total phosphorus and chlorophyll-a targets. For Bathtub modeling purposes, the lake was divided into two segments (see Figure D-1 of Appendix D of the TMDL document). The Lake Iowa TMDL document’s current model targeting approach uses surface area/mean depth with a single point of context in the lake. It is the EPA’s opinion that an area-weighted approach is a more protective target that holistically protects the integrity of the biological, chemical and physical conditions of any lake system. The approach used in the TMDL document is specific to a singular location in the lake, and offers a lower level of protection than the area-weighted approach used in some other TMDL documents developed by the IDNR. While the approach is less protective, it still provides protection of all designated uses for Lake Iowa. The numerical translation is also protective of the narrative criteria which includes, “…free from aesthetically objectionable conditions”.

"Water Quality Standards Attainment:
Casey Lake is a significant publicly owned lake, and is protected for the following designated uses: Primary Contact Recreation use Class A1, Lakes and Wetlands Aquatic Life Class B(LW) and Human Health Fish Consumption Class HH.
 
Although the state of Iowa does not have numeric criteria for algae or chlorophyll a, narrative water quality criteria do apply. Chapter 61.3(2) of the water quality standards contains the general water quality criteria, which are applicable to all surface waters.
 
61.3(2)c. ""Such waters shall be free from materials attributable to wastewater discharges or agricultural practices producing objectionable color, odor or other aesthetically objectionable conditions.""
 
The narrative criteria in the water quality standards require that Casey Lake be free from ""aesthetically objection-able conditions."" There are no numeric criteria associated with water clarity; therefore, attainment of the WQS is based on maintaining relatively good water clarity compared to other Iowa lakes. The primary metric for WQS attainment set forth in this TMDL is obtaining/ maintaining a chlorophyll a Carlson's trophic state index of no greater than 63, which corresponds to a chlorophyll a concentration of 27 micrograms per liter. The IDNR considers aesthetically objectionable conditions present in a water body when Carslon's TSI for the median growing season chlorophyll a or secchi depth exceeds 65. In order to delist a lake impaired by algae from the 303(d) list, the median growing season chlorophyll a TSI must not exceed 63 in two consecutive listing cycles, per the IDNR's listing methodology. 
 
With respect to pH, the same numeric criteria apply to Primary Contact Recreational Use Class A1, Lakes and Wetlands Aquatic Life Class B(LW) and Drinking Water Supply Class C. 

 
Per Sections 61.3(3)a(2), b(2) and c(3) of the WQS, ""The pH shall not be less than 6.5 nor greater than 9.0.""

actions.actionName: Iowa River Basin TMDL for Pathogen Indicators

documents.documentComments: This document is a correction to the June 2018 Approval Letter.
This is the Final EPA Approved Iowa River Basin TMDL.

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText: The critical period for the impairment occurs in the recreational season of March 15 to November 15. Attainment of the WQS to fully support primary contact recreation requires that the GM for E. coli concentrations be no greater than 126 orgs/100 mL and the single sample maximum (SSM) be not greater than 235 orgs/100 mL (Iowa Administrative Code 567, Chapter 61, Water Quality Standards for Class A1 uses). The methods used to develop the E. coli TMDLs for the Iowa River Basin are based on the assumption that compliance with the SSM will coincide with attainment of the GM targets set forth in this TMDL. Therefore, the loading capacity of each TMDL segment is the maximum number of E. coli organisms that can be in the stream while meeting the GM criterion of 126 orgs/100 mL. WQS will be attained in the impaired stream segments when the monitored E. coli concentration meets the GM criterion of 126 orgs/100 mL during the recreational season of March 15 – November 15. This TMDL will meet water quality standards.

The methods used to develop the E. coli TMDLs for the Iowa River Basin are based on the assumption that compliance with the SSM will coincide with attainment of the GM targets set forth in this TMDL. Therefore, the loading capacity of each TMDL segment is the maximum number of E. coli organisms that can be in the stream while meeting the GM criterion of 126 orgs/100 mL. WQS will be attained in the impaired stream segments when the monitored E. coli concentration meets the GM criterion of 126 orgs/100 mL during the recreational season of March 15 – November 15. This TMDL will meet water quality standards.

documents.documentComments: This is the Final EPA approved Hickory Grove Lake TMDL.

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText: Over-abundance of phosphorus is largely responsible for excessive algal growth, which impairs the primary contact designated use of Hickory Grove Lake. The impairments are addressed by development of a TMDL that limits total phosphorus (TP) loads to the lake. Phosphorus reductions should be accompanied by reduced algal growth and increased water clarity. This TMDL will meet Water Quality Standards.

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText: Reasonable assurance for reduction of nonpoint sources is provided by the list of potential best management practices that would deliver phosphorus reductions, a group of nonstructural practices that prevent transport of phosphorus, a proposed methodology for prioritizing and targeting BMPs on the landscape, and monitoring for best available data for estimating the reductions associated with implemented BMPs. This TMDL will meet Water Quality Standards.

Reasonable assurance for reduction of nonpoint sources is provided by the list of potential best management practices that would deliver phosphorus reductions, a group of nonstructural practices that prevent transport of phosphorus, a proposed methodology for prioritizing and targeting BMPs on the landscape, and monitoring for best available data for estimating the reductions associated with implemented BMPs. This TMDL will meet Water Quality Standards.

What can be done to improve Lake Orient?
Reducing phosphorus loss from pasture, row crops, and implementing or improving existing structural BMPs such as terraces, grass waterways, and constructed sediment basins in beneficial locations will significantly reduce phosphorus loads to the lake. Increasing the trapping efficiency of the existing sediment basins may be the most cost effective structural alternative. Consideration should be given to reductions in the population of grass carp, which graze on aquatic plants reducing the uptake of phosphorous. Finally, removal of curly-leaf pondweed and other invasive plant species will help improve water quality. Curly-leaf pondweed dies back in the summer releasing nutrients that contribute to algal blooms. This TMDL will meet Water Quality Standards.

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText: A Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) is required for Briggs Woods Lake by the Federal Clean Water Act. The WQIP for Briggs Woods Lake quantified the maximum amount of total phosphorus (TP) the lake can assimilate and still support primary contract recreation and aquatic life in the lake. It is assumed the TMDL for algae will also address the pH impairment since both are attributed to excess nutrients, particularly phosphorus. As a result, the amendment will not revisit the allowable TP load to the lake but refer to the 2012 WQIP for allowable phosphorus loads. This TMDL will meet WQS.

documents.documentComments: EPA Decision Document for Eldred Sherwood

This report serves multiple purposes. First, it is a resource for increased understanding of watershed and water quality conditions in and around Eldred Sherwood Lake. Second, it satisfies the Federal Clean Water Act requirement to develop a Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) for impaired waterbodies. Third, it provides a foundation for locally-driven watershed and water quality improvement efforts. Finally, it may be useful for obtaining financial assistance to implement projects to remove Eldred Sherwood Lake from the federal 303(d) list of impaired waters.

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText:
Decision criteria for WQS attainment
The narrative criteria in the water quality standards require that Eldred Sherwood Lake be free from “aesthetically objectionable conditions.” The metrics for WQS attainment for de-listing the impairments are a chlorophyll-a TSI of 63 or less in two consecutive 303(d) listing cycles. This TMDL will meet Water Quality Standards.

Decision criteria for WQS attainment
The narrative criteria in the water quality standards require that Eldred Sherwood Lake be free from “aesthetically objectionable conditions.” The metrics for WQS attainment for de-listing the impairments are a chlorophyll-a TSI of 63 or less in two consecutive 303(d) listing cycles. This TMDL will meet Water Quality Standards.

documents.documentComments: Iowa Submittal Letter to EPA for Meadow Lake TMDL

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText: Meadow Lake is impaired for excessive algae growth and turbidity. Data interpretation indicates that phosphorus load reduction will best address these impairments. The phosphorus loads to the lake lead to high levels of algal production.  Much of the phosphorus enters the lake attached to sediments. Therefore, practices to reduce phosphorus will also reduce any sediment levels impacting turbidity. The primary focus of the TMDL document is quantifying and reducing phosphorus loads to achieve water quality standards.The linkage between total phosphorus and the listed impairments is appropriate and will attain and maintain water quality standards.

Meadow Lake is impaired for excessive algae growth and turbidity. Data interpretation indicates that phosphorus load reduction will best address these impairments. The phosphorus loads to the lake lead to high levels of algal production.  Much of the phosphorus enters the lake attached to sediments. Therefore, practices to reduce phosphorus will also reduce any sediment levels impacting turbidity. The primary focus of the TMDL document is quantifying and reducing phosphorus loads to achieve water quality standards.The linkage between total phosphorus and the listed impairments is appropriate and will attain and maintain water quality standards.

WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
THE IOWA WQS (IAC 567-61) LIST THE DESIGNATED USES FOR BLUE LAKE AS PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATIONAL USE (CLASS A1), AQUATIC LIFE (CLASS B(LW)) AND HUMAN HEALTH (CLASS HH).  MORE RECENT ASSESSMENTS IN 2006 REVEALED THAT THE CLASS A1 DESIGNATED USE WAS ASSESSED (MONITORED) AS "NOT BEING SUPPORTED" DUE TO EXCESSIVE SUSPENDED ALGAE FROM HIGH PHOSPHORUS LOADING AND INORGANIC TURBIDITY.  THE CLASS B(LW) DESIGNATED USE WAS ASSESSED (EVALUATED) AS "FULLY SUPPORTING."   THE CLASS HH FISH CONSUMPTION USES REMAIN "NOT ASSESSED" DUE TO THE LACK OF RECENT FISH CONTAMINANT MONITORING.  
 
IOWA DOES NOT HAVE NUMERIC WATER QUALITY CRITERIA FOR ALGAE OR TURBIDITY.  FOR ALGAE AND TURBIDITY THE IMPAIRMENT IS BASED ON NARRATIVE STANDARDS WHICH STATE THAT BLUE LAKE SHOULD BE "FREE FROM MATERIALS ATTRIBUTABLE TO WASTEWATER DISCHARGES OR AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES PRODUCING OBJECTIONABLE COLOR, ODOR, OR OTHER AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS."  THE CRITERIA FOR ASSESSING LAKE ALGAE AND TURBIDITY IMPAIRMENT ARE BASED ON TSI SCORES FOR CHLOROPHYLL A AND SD.  THE 305(B) ASSESSMENT IMPAIRMENT THRESHOLDS FOR NUISANCE CONDITIONS ARE TSI VALUES OF 65 FOR BOTH CHLOROPHYLL A AND SD, GIVING A TARGET CHLOROPHYLL A CONCENTRATION OF 33 UG/L AND A TARGET SD OF 0.7 METERS.  THE AVERAGE ANNUAL TP CONCENTRATION GOAL FOR THESE TARGETS HAS BEEN ESTIMATED AT 59 UG/L, USING THE BATHTUB MODEL.

associatedPollutants.TMDLEndPointText:
WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT:
THE ASSIGNED BENEFICIAL USES FOR THE EAST FORK DES MOINES RIVER ARE CLASS A1 (PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATION), CLASS B (WW1) (AQUATIC LIFE), AND HIGH QUALITY RESOURCE WATER.  THE USE THAT IS IMPAIRED IS CLASS A1.  THE APPLICABLE WQS IS A SINGLE SAMPLE MAXIMUM NOT TO EXCEED  235 E. COLI CFU/100 ML DURING THE RECREATIONAL SEASON.  AN ADDITIONAL WQS IS A GEOMETRIC MEAN NOT TO EXCEED 126 CFU/100 ML DURING THE RECREATIONAL SEASON.  THE RECREATIONAL SEASON IS DEFINED IN THE IOWA WQS AS THE PERIOD FROM MARCH 15 THROUGH NOVEMBER 15.  THESE CRITERIA APPLY TO CLASS A1 WATERS IN THE STATE OF IOWA.  
 
THE SEGMENT ADDRESSED IN THIS TMDL (IA 04-EDM-0010_1) WAS FIRST INCLUDED ON AN IMPAIRED WATERS LIST IN 1998 AS IMPAIRED FOR INDICATOR BACTERIA.  THE CURRENT WQS FOR INDICATOR BACTERIA ARE BASED ON E. COLI RATHER THAN FECAL COLIFORM AND THIS TMDL ADDRESSES E. COLI.
 
EPA AGREES THAT THE SUBMITTAL ADDRESSES THE PROPER WQS FOR THE IMPAIRMENT.

THE USE THAT IS IMPAIRED IS CLASS A1.  MORE RECENT ASSESSMENTS IN 2006 REVEALED THAT THE CLASS A1 DESIGNATED USE WAS ASSESSED (MONITORED) AS "PARTIALLY SUPPORTING" DUE TO VERY POOR WATER TRANSPARENCY RESULTING PRIMARILY FROM HIGH LEVELS OF NON-ALGAL TURBIDITY AND THE CLASS B USE WAS ASSESSED (EVALUATED) AS "FULLY  SUPPORTING."  THE LOST ISLAND LAKE PRIMARY CONTACT RECREATIONAL USE HAS BEEN ASSESSED USING NARRATIVE CRITERIA FOR AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS AS NOT SUPPORTING THE CLASS A1 USE.  THE RECREATIONAL SEASON IS DEFINED IN THE IOWA WQS AS THE PERIOD FROM MARCH 15 THROUGH NOVEMBER 15.
 
IOWA DOES NOT HAVE NUMERIC WATER QUALITY CRITERIA FOR ALGAE OR TURBIDITY.  THE ALGAE AND TURBIDITY IMPAIRMENT IS BASED ON NARRATIVE STANDARDS WHICH STATE THAT LOST ISLAND LAKE SHOULD BE "FREE FROM MATERIALS ATTRIBUTABLE TO WASTEWATER DISCHARGES OR AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES PRODUCING OBJECTIONABLE COLOR, ODOR, OR OTHER AESTHETICALLY OBJECTIONABLE CONDITIONS."  THE CRITERIA FOR ASSESSING LAKE ALGAE AND TURBIDITY IMPAIRMENT ARE BASED ON TSI SCORES FOR CHLOROPHYLL AND SD.  A NUMERIC TRANSLATOR TSI WAS USED TO ADDRESS THE NARRATIVE STANDARD.  THE PHOSPHORUS TARGET WAS DETERMINED USING THE BATHTUB LAKE NUTRIENT MODEL.
